subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Re: how to transcribe air and ear
msgSnippet: ... It seems we have several north-american-west-coast English speakers on this list, and I think the accent is fairly consistent from San Diego right up into
messageBody:
On Tue 2007.10.30, at 16:27, pgabhart wrote:
What I am wondering is how do you pronounce the word "awe" itself as in what one experiences in connection with the deity?  Does that also come out as "ah"?  I have difficulty imagining someone saying, "I stand in ah before God."  To me that is the sound the doctor tells you to make before using a tongue depressor, not a separate word by itself.

It seems we have several north-american-west-coast English speakers on this list, and I think the accent is fairly consistent from San Diego right up into Alaska.  I myself am from San Francisco, but I have traveled and lived in several countries which use very differently-pronounced versions of English and have come to hear the distinctions between ah, awe and ox.  In my own natural speech, they are distinguished but only very slightly: this often causes people in my home region to ask where I come from.  I had to choose one of the letters to write the initial sound of my name in QuickScript, and chose awe though my pronunciation is probably closer to ah.

Having read a few books written in 'dialect spelling' (Trainspotting for one), I have to say that I really prefer having a standard spelling which 'washes out' some of the regional differences rather than having to learn several different spellings for the same word.  (I have always had a hell of a time understanding Scottish speakers of English in particular.)  I do not think of QuickScript as a means of writing in ones own dialect, but rather a means of more closely (not exactly) approximating the sounds of the spoken language and reforming spelling.  I took Paul's original message to be a suggestion for standardized spelling, though it appears I may have misjudged that.  In such an endeavor, however, I don't think we need to slavishly stick to a single source for pronunciation (the OED vs. Websters vs. ...).  I think the spirit of QuickScript can be noted in Read's attempts to remove cases of contention, such as using simply ing as a suffix rather than choosing between it-ing or eat-ing.

As an aside, I wonder how one would render the common greeting/appellation/exclaimation "dude," the way I grew up hearing and pronouncing it.  Perhaps day-eat-ooze-day, though there is a dipthong between the two vowels which is not well captured by that spelling nor the ye-ooze combination in the QS manual.  It is the same sound people here on the west coast might make when presented with something unappealing to eat, "ewwww."

oliver

On Tue 2007.10.30, at 16:27, pgabhart wrote:
> What I am wondering is how do you pronounce the word "awe" itself  
> as in what one experiences in connection with the deity?  Does that  
> also come out as "ah"?  I have difficulty imagining someone saying,  
> "I stand in ah before God."  To me that is the sound the doctor  
> tells you to make before using a tongue depressor, not a separate  
> word by itself.

It seems we have several north-american-west-coast English speakers  
on this list, and I think the accent is fairly consistent from San  
Diego right up into Alaska.  I myself am from San Francisco, but I  
have traveled and lived in several countries which use very  
differently-pronounced versions of English and have come to hear the  
distinctions between ah, awe and ox.  In my own natural speech, they  
are distinguished but only very slightly: this often causes people in  
my home region to ask where I come from.  I had to choose one of the  
letters to write the initial sound of my name in QuickScript, and  
chose awe though my pronunciation is probably closer to ah.

Having read a few books written in 'dialect spelling' (Trainspotting  
for one), I have to say that I really prefer having a standard  
spelling which 'washes out' some of the regional differences rather  
than having to learn several different spellings for the same word.   
(I have always had a hell of a time understanding Scottish speakers  
of English in particular.)  I do not think of QuickScript as a means  
of writing in ones own dialect, but rather a means of more closely  
(not exactly) approximating the sounds of the spoken language and  
reforming spelling.  I took Paul's original message to be a  
suggestion for standardized spelling, though it appears I may have  
misjudged that.  In such an endeavor, however, I don't think we need  
to slavishly stick to a single source for pronunciation (the OED vs.  
Websters vs. ...).  I think the spirit of QuickScript can be noted in  
Read's attempts to remove cases of contention, such as using simply  
ing as a suffix rather than choosing between it-ing or eat-ing.

As an aside, I wonder how one would render the common greeting/ 
appellation/exclaimation "dude," the way I grew up hearing and  
pronouncing it.  Perhaps day-eat-ooze-day, though there is a dipthong  
between the two vowels which is not well captured by that spelling  
nor the ye-ooze combination in the QS manual.  It is the same sound  
people here on the west coast might make when presented with  
something unappealing to eat, "ewwww."

oliver



--Apple-Mail-3-874074948
